Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Implementation of Genetic Algorithms for Personalized Chemosensitivity Testing for Cancer Patients
Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers are investigating a direct approach to evaluate chemotherapy effectiveness, where tumor tissue that has been extracted from a patient is exposed to clinically relevant treatments in an environment that closely mimics the human body. Through monitoring and analysis methods, researchers are able to determine which chemotherapies appear to be most effective in treating a patient?s cancer. These results can be used synergistically with current gene expression methods to improve predicting patient response to all therapies including chemotherapy. In the proposed process, researchers provide a mechanism for determining the efficacy of a cancer treatment directly on living biopsied tissue. This method is not dependent on historical statistical correlations to predict patient treatment and outcome. Researchers propose to predict therapeutic patient response more accurately by precisely measuring drug efficacy directly on cultured tumor tissue. This method is designed to be a high throughput real-time assay using genetic algorithms for automated data capture.

Currently, clinicians choose chemotherapy treatment options for their patients according to the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines and historical clinical outcome results for patients with similar types of breast cancer. Historically this approach has had limited success since less than 10% of breast cancer patients receiving chemotherapy are thought to exhibit absolute improvement. Researchers aim to provide oncologists and pathologists with information to better determine the best FDA approved chemotherapeutic option for their patients. The proposed method, if successful, will be provided as a service requested by an oncologist and pathologist, similar to other current forms of clinical diagnostic testing, such as medical imaging, blood work, etc. This method has the potential to be expanded to all other solid tumor cancers as well as being adapted to testing novel therapeutic agents.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project is an artificial intelligence based automated microscopy guidance system used in personalized chemotherapy efficacy measurement for cancer patients. Our system is implemented as software and installed into a commercial fluorescent or confocal microscope to command its focusing and image capturing functions.

Typically, tumor samples taken from a cancer patient are placed into a microscope plate with multiple container wells (e.g., 96-well plates are popular) filled with gel containing nutrients for cancer cells to live (similar to within a body). Into each well, a different chemotherapy cocktail with a different dosage is injected. These wells are then observed for many days (e.g., a week or longer), during which time microscopic pictures are taken periodically (e.g., every hour). These pictures are analyzed to determine which drug cocktail in what dosage was the most effective in killing cancer cells for this patient. However, this operation is prohibitively costly since patient tumor tissue is alive and moves inside a well, requiring a technician to re-focus the microscope every few hours for each well (e.g., thousands of re-focus operations for a single patient. Figure 1 demonstrates losing focus with a standard microscope (top pane) versus keeping focus with our AI-based based microscopy in 3-D culture system (bottom pane) for a breast cancer cell line MCF-7.

Our system replaces this infeasibly labor-intensive task by automating focusing and image capturing functions of a microscope with the help of AI algorithms. Our system enables oncologists to compare the impacts of different drugs on patient tumor tissue over prolonged periods of time (such as days or weeks). In Figure 2, an output of our system is shown, where impact of different drugs can be clearly seen for a breast cancer cell line MCF-7.

With the help of this NSF grant, we demonstrated the feasibility of this system using breast and colorectal cancer cell lines in laboratories of Biology Department at the City College of New York. During our experiments, we collaborated with scientists in Biology Department in CCNY and Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

As part of this grant, we applied for a utility patent and published over 10 peer-reviewed conference and journal papers. Our project is an excellent example of technology transfer: it applies the AI algorithms developed under our previous NSF grant for robotics into personalized cancer treatment.

Commercialization of our system requires a partnership with a cancer center to fine-tune the drug efficacy decisions by our AI algorithms. Since the image capturing and analysis by our AI algorithms can also be combined with genetic knowledge of a given patient, we believe that our system has a potential to be one of the important players in personalized cancer therapy.
